newsitem.title: USA: Versace set seal on Miami Beach transformation.
newsitem.headline: Versace set seal on Miami Beach transformation.

text.p: Miami Beach, the site of designer Gianni Versace's murder, has transformed itself over 20 years from a crumbling retiree backwater to one of the world's glitziest hotspots.
Versace's arrival five years ago seemed to set the seal on the area's makeover.

In 1992, the trend-setting designer bought an old apartment house on the beachfront Ocean Drive, by then a centre for jet-setting fashion and tourism. He rehabilitated the building into an award-winning Mediterranean mansion, knocking down a hotel next door to build gardens and a pool.

Versace became one of the first big-name designers to set up shop at the trendy southern end of Miami Beach, known as South Beach, when he established a boutique just blocks from his house. He opened the doors of his residence for glittering business, social and charitable events.

"That such an international figure would want to make South Beach one of his homes, shows that ... the progress had reached such a point that it was worth his time and effort, that it was exciting for him," said Eugene Patron, a board member at the South Beach Business Guild.
"It was the icing on the cake," he said.

But Versace also won friends by acting like just another part of the community, a man who walked around his neighbourhood to buy coffee or books while other local celebrities spent their days in limousines, flanked by bodyguards.

It was after one of his morning walks that Versace was shot and killed on Tuesday morning, gunned down in broad daylight on the steps of his mansion by a man police called a serial killer and homosexual prostitute.
The loss plunged the neighbourhood into shock and mourning.

Community leaders rushed to remind potential visitors that the killing was an extraordinary event and the Art Deco neighbourhood remained the glamorous paradise that had attracted the fashion magnate.
"Let me assure you that Miami Beach and Dade County are safe despite this terrible incident," Dade County Mayor Alex Penelas told a news conference after Versace's death.
Miami Beach was founded in the 1920s by car-dealing millionaire Carl Fisher, who dreamed of turning a mosquito-ridden swamp into Florida's version of St. Tropez.
It was built up in the 1930s with dozens of Art Deco hotels, featuring pastel colours and curved lines similar to the modernist style popular for automobiles of the day.

In the 1950s, Miami Beach saw the construction of sprawling hotel "pleasure palaces" such as the Fountainebleau, which attracted stars like Joan Crawford, Frank Sinatra and Jackie Gleason, who filmed his television show there.
But by the 1970s, Miami Beach's buildings and population were showing their age, and the one-time vacation hotspot became known as "God's waiting room."
The rebirth began in the 1970s, when activists founded the Miami Beach Design Preservation League and urged the restoration, not demolition, of old hotels.
Miami Beach's historic Art Deco District was established in 1976 and South Beach became the first 20th century neighbourhood on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.
By the 1990s, when Versace and other celebrities became mainstays on its streets, the area had become a white-hot vacation spot.
Local activists called Versace's death a tragedy, but said they disagreed with those who gave the designer all the credit for reviving South Beach.

"He certainly played a significant role in Miami Beach, but to credit him with the renaissance of south Miami Beach is a mistake, a flat-out mistake," said Randall Robinson, preservation planner with the Miami Design Preservation League.
"Abraham Lincoln played a huge role in American history, but he wasn't one of the founding fathers," he said.
